msContents.summary: Personal letter of a woman to several people (some part of her family) speaking of the relationship to another woman and delivery of wine

msItem.note: Written along the fibers on the front; the letter continues on the back across the fibers
There is a large number of phonetic mistakes

18 lines of writing probably by a single hand, which is large, practiced, and legible except when the ink runs out; the intralinear addition between lines 2-3 was probably added by the same hand with a different pen

supportDesc.support: 1papyrus fragment, broken on the bottom ; 13.5 x 15 cm

provenance.p: Purchased by Columbia University from M. Nahman through H.I. Bell, in July 1923; no. 57 (5.C.68) in Bell's inventory

div.ab: (Front) To my truly most admirable brothers my master Petros and Elias, Paladia and wife Tegrape and Elias and Maria, greetings. Above all I thank God concerning your . . . my lord son Petros. Since you left me, I am getting along with your (?) . . . . and up till today I stayed with her, and I do not leave her. (traces) (Back) And I Tegrape have written to my brothers Elias and Petros and Maria. I thank brothers Petros and Elias. Therefore (?) ask the landlord to deliver the wine to us . . . Since you left here, I am alone for a year, we have received nothing. You sent two cog-wheels and one sphairion; I gave them for . . .; bring another one here and the things there . . .
